abstract: New rules from Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other tech products, reflect a major shift in how electronics companies view Chinese labor practices.
snippet: New rules from Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other tech products, reflect a major shift in how electronics companies view Chinese labor practices.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Hewlett-Packard, one of the world’s largest makers of computers and other electronics, is imposing new limits on the employment of students and temporary agency workers at factories across China. The move, following recent efforts by Apple to increase scrutiny of student workers, reflects a significant shift in how electronics companies view problematic labor practices in China.

headline.main: H.P. Directs Its Suppliers in China to Limit Student Labor
headline.print_headline: Hewlett Pushes China to Limit Student Labor

byline.original: By Keith Bradsher and David Barboza

abstract: David Einhorn says he still loves Apple, but the company needs to change. | The Federal Reserve may be increasing its effort to spot bubbles on Wall Street. | The charges in the government’s lawsuit against Standard & Poor’s are reminiscent of what happened at Arthur Andersen. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is preparing for a new life in London.
snippet: David Einhorn says he still loves Apple, but the company needs to change. | The Federal Reserve may be increasing its effort to spot bubbles on Wall Street. | The charges in the government’s lawsuit against Standard & Poor’s are reminiscent of wha...
lead_paragraph: David Einhorn says he still loves Apple. But the company needs to change, the hedge fund manager says. Mr. Einhorn, head of Greenlight Capital, filed a lawsuit on Thursday to block a plan by Apple to eliminate preferred shares and urged fellow shareholders to join him. “The standoff sets up an unusual clash between two sides who can each claim a huge following on Wall Street,” DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced writes.

abstract: Analysts have been overwhelmingly bullish on Apple stock, even at $705 a share. Now that the stock has dropped 36 percent, they still recommend investors buy it, though some are starting to waver.
snippet: Analysts have been overwhelmingly bullish on Apple stock, even at $705 a share. Now that the stock has dropped 36 percent, they still recommend investors buy it, though some are starting to waver.
lead_paragraph: Analysts have been overwhelmingly bullish on Apple stock, even at $705 a share. Now that the stock has dropped 36 percent, they still recommend investors buy it, though some are starting to waver.

abstract: Even with reforms meant to reduce conflicts of interest, many analysts failed to foresee a plunge in Apple’s shares.
snippet: Even with reforms meant to reduce conflicts of interest, many analysts failed to foresee a plunge in Apple’s shares.
lead_paragraph: Last September, Apple shares hit a record $705. And to the overwhelming majority of Wall Street analysts, that meant one thing: buy.

headline.main: Following a Herd of Bulls on Apple
headline.print_headline: Following A Herd Of Bulls On Apple
